data.text: Schnabel: Due to the specific character of this pandemic, the risk of zombification may be less pronounced than during other times. Please read my column with @laeven_luc & @gschepen, which proposes some policy measures #AskECB https://t.co/tUj6iwLGHW. https://t.co/eAbEPUaqEo

Schnabel: It is important that fiscal and monetary policies work hand in hand to overcome this deep crisis. The role of monetary policy is now to preserve favourable financing conditions and support the recovery. This will also improve the fiscal situation. #AskECB https://t.co/y07eup7dZL

Schnabel: Currently it is foreseen that net purchases are conducted until at least March 2022 and reinvestments until end-2023. The duration of the PEPP will depend on the evolution of the pandemic and its consequences for the economic and inflation outlook. #AskECB https://t.co/MKVNMakUlQ

Schnabel: The allocation of public asset purchases is guided by the capital key. The PEPP allows for deviations to counter fragmentation in the euro area. All deviations under the PEPP/PSPP can be inferred from our website #AskECB https://t.co/UWeApCuYTp https://t.co/2pRcyv290v

Schnabel: Group think is best avoided by involving people from diverse backgrounds in our decision-making. The ECB benefits from having people from all over the euro area. Gender equality is also important, and we are actively pursuing gender equality. #AskECB https://t.co/fhvJPHt1TA

Schnabel: We are exploring how the ECB can contribute to the fight against climate change within our mandate. I support this process in all relevant areas like economic modelling, risk assessment, disclosure, monetary policy operations and own investments. #AskECB https://t.co/6b93R3jW4B

Schnabel: Our monetary policy is effective. Economic growth & inflation would be lower without it. Green bonds are part of our portfolio and help to reduce the carbon footprint. We are reflecting more on climate issues with respect to our policies in the strategy review. #AskECB https://t.co/ZZoTNxDt0c

Schnabel: In the short run fiscal support must not be withdrawn prematurely. In the long run we need a debate about common fiscal instruments at European level and a reform of the fiscal framework. We are monitoring the impact of our policies on asset prices carefully. #AskECB https://t.co/24zxkB50b9
Schnabel: A cancellation of national debts would constitute a clear violation of the European Treaties. The debate is harmful and should be stopped. #AskECB https://t.co/SGukE8afKK

Schnabel: It is very encouraging to see that other central banks are taking action in the fight against climate change. The @ecb will discuss its own potential actions with respect to climate change in our monetary policy strategy review. #AskECB https://t.co/IoX4JjVqnA

Schnabel: The tiering system is working as intended, namely to preserve the accommodative impact of our negative interest rate policy while alleviating its most direct negative side effects for banks. We are continuously monitoring the development of excess liquidity. #AskECB https://t.co/HSYuCt3kvr

Schnabel: Monetary policy in the euro area is complicated by the fact that there are 19 sovereign bond markets and that safe haven flows may cause fragmentation within the euro area. A European safe asset would mitigate such destabilising safe haven flows. #AskECB https://t.co/Bix4pqXFzH

Schnabel: The @ecb aims to avoid prices rising too fast or too slow so that consumers can rely on stable prices. In doing so, it helps the economy to recover from downturns & avoids the economy running hot. Decisions are based on our legal rules, economic analysis & data. #AskECB https://t.co/Vcxmb3FUWH

Good afternoon, this is @Isabel_Schnabel, Executive Board member @ecb. I’m looking forward to answer your questions for the next 45 minutes or so. Join the conversation! #AskECB https://t.co/C7ququi9oF
Working paper: What value added in the trade balances of euro area financial centres? https://t.co/FYfosdA9wP
Working paper: Daily tracker of global economic activity - A close-up of the COVID-19 pandemic https://t.co/zWfhEMi4Q2
Later today: Send us your question using #AskECB and join the Twitter Q&A with our Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel! https://t.co/6COc2CLd8j

Read the full speech in German or English:
https://t.co/2OKJdmyXf8 (DE)
https://t.co/oxBHhLd15D (EN)

Public trust is crucial to ensure the effectiveness of the ECB’s monetary policy and safeguard central bank independence, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. To foster trust, the ECB needs to expand its communication efforts to reach all European citizens. https://t.co/4RuMlHVjc2
(For German speakers) Watch live from 17:00 CET: Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel talks about the importance of trust for the ECB’s monetary policy @his_hamburg https://t.co/K6tuAQMGz3
Letter from Andrea Enria, Chair of the Supervisory Board, to Mr Papadimoulis, MEP, on a bank under ECB supervision https://t.co/pN3pwi1Xb2 (EN) https://t.co/6PU90tDU8p (EL)
Enria: If banks operate within the boundaries set in the recommendation, they could distribute an estimated total amount of €10-12 billion, about one-third of the distribution in a normal year.

The ECB recommendation to refrain from or limit dividends until September 2021 signals gradual return to normalcy, Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria tells @BloombergTV in an interview. https://t.co/kWyHTH5Xup

The ECB asks banks to consider the ongoing uncertainty and to refrain from or limit dividends until 30 September 2021 to preserve their capacity to lend and absorb losses. Dividends should not exceed 15% of 2019-20 profits and 20 basis points of CET1 ratio https://t.co/taibTjFbt9 https://t.co/QlachQFnE3
Speech Philip R. Lane: The resilience of the euro https://t.co/tyRb18SrCd (slides)
Working paper: The impact of US tariffs against China on US imports - Evidence for trade diversion? https://t.co/3Sc3kgexJ9
Working paper: On the origin of systemic risk https://t.co/9J2TFG3DM2

Want to know exactly how the appointment procedure for ECB Executive Board members works? Check out our explainer to find out ⬇️
https://t.co/T3nSvI3pkT
Welcome @FrankElderson, who takes up his position as ECB Executive Board member today. We wish him all the best for his eight-year term of office. https://t.co/aMu3ErpF0Z

Today marks Yves Mersch’s last day as a member of the ECB’s Executive Board and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board. We sadly cannot say farewell in person, but would like to thank him for all his work on the European project and wish him all the best for the future. https://t.co/XsA4SdqrR3
Welcome address by @Isabel_Schnabel at the third roundtable on euro risk-free rates https://t.co/rSAo1JeBYT
Working paper: Weigh(t)ing the basket - Aggregate and component-based inflation forecasts for the euro area https://t.co/Kltz0sjWIC
Working paper: Whatever it takes to save the planet? Central banks and unconventional green policy https://t.co/wO9z3hAeOj

Panetta: We will exit this crisis with higher public and private debt levels, so achieving growth rates that remain higher than interest rates will be crucial. By 2026 Next Generation EU funds could increase real output in the euro area by up to 1.5% https://t.co/rTxTq6Dc97 6/6

Panetta: Governments need to wisely use the fiscal space created by monetary policy and key decisions at European level – in particular joint EU borrowing. Productive investment spending can lift potential growth and enhance debt sustainability 5/6

Panetta: Our commitment is linked to supporting the return of inflation to our aim in a sustained way. Financing conditions need to remain very supportive as growth accelerates. As a result, monetary policy will become more accommodative relative to the growth outlook 4/6

Panetta: Over the coming months, where uncertainty is still high and the private sector reluctant to take risks, fiscal policy will remain a key channel for transmitting monetary policy. When uncertainty recedes, transmission through the private sector will gain traction 3/6

Panetta: The increase in the envelope of our pandemic emergency purchase programme to €1.85 trillion gives us considerable firepower. It allows us to respond flexibly at any time and with the necessary force to resist a premature tightening of financing conditions 2/6

(THREAD) Policymakers must continue providing certainty to the economy, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. For monetary policy, this means providing certainty about financing conditions well into the future. Last week the ECB Governing Council did just that 1/6 #RIF2020 https://t.co/qv3bZMEQxu

The ECB and governments have put in place measures to support bank lending during the crisis. These loans help healthy companies cope – but are they also keeping non-viable “zombie” firms alive as critics claim? Read our Explainer https://t.co/f7HYiqySV8 https://t.co/VQO7ZJnkGi
Working paper: Contagion accounting https://t.co/X1mubm2tFL
Working paper: Benefits of macro-prudential policy in low interest rate environments https://t.co/1tgaAWZxYr
Watch again: Lagarde on our determination to maintain favourable financing conditions https://t.co/Q3pu4PuezU
Press release: ECB prolongs support via targeted lending operations for banks that lend to the real economy https://t.co/tdBsmBAFk0
Press release: ECB extends pandemic emergency longer-term refinancing operations https://t.co/6JU7fpNIfX

ECB staff macroeconomic projections for the euro area (December 2020) https://t.co/Az8ogrFs6C 

Projection charts and tables https://t.co/1NoOzFNxdA https://t.co/HYyhNCDjEi
Introductory statement by President Christine Lagarde to the press conference https://t.co/w3zk9E0ZlL
ECB President Christine Lagarde introduces the baseline GDP and inflation outlook for the euro area. https://t.co/honGHMMChG
Watch the ECB press conference live: President Christine Lagarde explains today’s monetary policy decisions https://t.co/74s5gmTojk
Coming up in 15 minutes: ECB President Christine Lagarde explains today’s monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/DkXqjN644J
Press release: Monetary policy decisions  https://t.co/koy8zAVy9m
Later today: watch live as ECB President Christine Lagarde explains the latest monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/yAicTObZAX
Euro area securities issues statistics (Oct 2020) https://t.co/tFcv4tGaFv
Letter from Andrea Enria, Chair of the Supervisory Board, to Mr Zanni, Ms Donato, Mr Grant and Mr Rinaldi, on non-performing loans https://t.co/rJlt5QtJ27 (EN) https://t.co/bTS8wwTNp1 (IT)
Letter from Andrea Enria, Chair of the Supervisory Board, to Mr Garicano, MEP, on dividend distributions https://t.co/PTQZH48P7k

McCaul: Postponing proactive credit risk management would probably lead to an amplified credit squeeze and cause strong cliff effects. This would also delay the recovery. Read the Supervision Blog https://t.co/fLhiRMjVx2 3/3

McCaul: Banks must put in place the necessary tools to recognise vulnerable borrowers at an early stage and to assess, measure and manage credit risk proactively. They must also improve transparency about their borrowers’ health 2/3

(THREAD) By strengthening credit practices now we improve the effectiveness of monetary policy transmission through the lending channel and of other support measures, writes Supervisory Board member Elizabeth McCaul. This helps avoid debt overhang effects and procyclicality 1/3 https://t.co/PoQSFpcamE

If all the support offered during the pandemic ended at once, it could pull the rug from under people’s feet, says economist Tamarah Shakir. Find out more about the challenges that lie ahead for financial stability on #TheECBPodcast with host @MichaelSteen https://t.co/43ndLavxD8 https://t.co/dObMWnA3WU

Bank boards’ role in ensuring effective controls and sound risk taking is particularly important in a crisis, says Supervisory Board member Elizabeth McCaul at an @FBF_School seminar. She discusses pressing governance issues and supervisory expectations https://t.co/OonsszLeNu https://t.co/3mpVqIWRKc

We cannot live unrestricted lives until there is mass vaccination, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells Reuters.  The biggest challenge for next year is reconciling the need to control the virus with the importance of supporting the economy. Full interview https://t.co/88LghiaXNk https://t.co/b3LELLvsOP
Occasional paper: Liquidity in resolution - Comparing frameworks for liquidity provision across jurisdictions https://t.co/u3FkKzuqLj
Occasional paper: Fiscal transfers and economic convergence https://t.co/PpkmutGl39

Policy measures have provided massive support to the economy during the pandemic but what could happen if they end abruptly or continue for even longer?
Find out in our Financial Stability Review and #TheECBPodcast.
Review https://t.co/InGfVGK0vg 
Podcast https://t.co/43ndLavxD8 https://t.co/zhAo3gEn34

Our latest study results suggest no single means of payment currently available meets all consumer needs, Executive Board member Fabio Panetta writes in a blog post. That’s why it is important to continue giving people a choice about how to pay https://t.co/S4mKNynZN6 https://t.co/VHglpMFanR
ECB appoints two senior managers for banking supervision https://t.co/vNP9dR9X8F
Euro area bank interest rate statistics (Oct 2020) https://t.co/zqKjlISbhr

We want to keep giving you the freedom to choose how you pay. That’s why we work to ensure that cash remains accepted and accessible, while promoting innovation in digital payments, such as a digital euro. Read more about the study results https://t.co/qSfsR5UBMa 4/4
The trend towards cashless payments seems to have been accelerated by the pandemic. However, more than half of respondents want to keep the option of paying with cash 3/4

Last year, people in the eurozone used cash for 73% of their retail transactions, compared to 79% in 2016. Their use of cards increased from 19% to 24% and almost four out of ten card transactions were made using contactless technology 2/4

(THREAD) How do people like to pay in the eurozone? Our latest study shows that cash was still the most used means of payment for retail transactions at the end of 2019, but its use is gradually declining https://t.co/qSfsR5UBMa 1/4 https://t.co/yOYkxTE49v
Want to know more about this? Have a look at the latest Financial Stability Review https://t.co/cesUgJN8Mc

In the latest #TheECBPodcast episode, our guest @JohnPCFell explains what financial stability is and why financial stability can be compared to cycling. Want to hear more? Tune into the conversation with our host @MichaelSteen https://t.co/43ndLavxD8 https://t.co/IyMOpe02xW

The current level of financing conditions provides substantial support to the economy, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel in an interview with @Bloomberg. The focus should now be on preserving these favourable conditions for as long as necessary https://t.co/py6TNo9BOG https://t.co/z1CNfx9mD9
Euro area insurance corporation statistics (Q3 2020) https://t.co/dxNrPUzCTT

Hakkarainen: Our digital future will be based on artificial intelligence and smart data architecture which will allow us to gradually spend much more effort and time on enriching our supervisory judgement and to deliver state-of-the-art supervision https://t.co/SOLgwR9cN2 2/2

THREAD) Fully harnessing technology will transform banking supervision, says Supervisory Board member @PenaHakkarainen at the Supervision Innovators Conference. European banking supervision aims to be at the forefront of this digital transformation 1/2 https://t.co/KdTocoOSKN

In European banking supervision we are thinking big, says Andrea Enria at the Supervision Innovators Conference. We want to use the digital transformation for banking supervision and to design supervisory technology that can be used worldwide https://t.co/GwqKp2oK7g https://t.co/FQFH19QAMr

Read more about green finance and what the ECB is doing to address climate change:

➡️ in our latest Financial Stability Review https://t.co/tHC02puqSO  

➡️ on our website https://t.co/SUGjLEiPSR 4/4

Green bonds support a transition to a more sustainable economy and can help bring EU capital markets closer together as we strive for a fully fledged capital markets union. See more on this in an interview by Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel  https://t.co/dNcUIR15KF 3/4
Buying green bonds from across Europe increases portfolio diversity, which makes investments less vulnerable to fluctuations and shocks in the domestic economy 2/4 https://t.co/f9Q4ZpwiIj
(THREAD) When investors go green, they go European, ongoing research by ECB and @DNB_NL economists shows. Home bias in the green bond market is much weaker than in the bond market as a whole 1/4
Working paper: How do banking groups react to macroprudential policies? Cross-border spillover effects of higher capital buffers on lending, risk-taking and internal markets https://t.co/TOogUTRwYg

Χωρίς ευρωπαϊκή εγγύηση καταθέσεων, η τραπεζική ένωση παραμένει ημιτελής και δεν μπορούμε να αποκομίσουμε τα οφέλη της, λέει στην @ERTsocial ο Αντρέα Ενρία, Προέδρος του Εποπτικού Συμβουλίου της ΕΚΤ. Μιλάει επίσης για την πρόοδο των ελληνικών τραπεζών https://t.co/DyfvKAqzDi https://t.co/4vP8eoco8K

Without European deposit insurance, the banking union remains incomplete and segmented and we cannot reap its benefits, Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria tells @ERTsocial. He also talks about the need for a bad bank and about Brexit https://t.co/9HBxDLhrPT https://t.co/JHBGIp3Mqq

Yves Mersch dresse un bilan critique mais optimiste de l’intégration de la zone euro depuis le traité de Maastricht dans un entretien avec @lemondefr. « Pour devenir maître de son sort, l’Europe devra résoudre ses déficiences structurelles. » https://t.co/6655a0uVgp https://t.co/1rChQjDNQx

Executive Board member Yves Mersch reflects on the achievements and shortcomings of euro area integration since the Maastricht Treaty in an interview with @lemondefr. To be master of its own destiny, Europe needs to solve its structural weaknesses https://t.co/hyJ70tT6gQ https://t.co/EG7JuL6rZS

Talous todennäköisimmin supistuu neljännesvuositasolla loppuvuonna, mutta elpyminen alkanee vuonna 2021 ja jatkunee vuonna 2022, EKP:n varapääjohtaja Luis de Guindos toteaa @hsfi haastattelussa. Tärkein tekijä lähitulevaisuudessa on rokotteen saatavuus https://t.co/iVoRQixUHR https://t.co/gpxbAkeTG3

De Guindos: The EU recovery fund is a very positive response to the crisis, also because it sends a clear signal of the willingness to defend Europe. But this money must be spent properly to make our economy greener, more digital and more competitive https://t.co/R7ai6UhR4N 3/3

De Guindos: The weak point of European banks is low profitability, which is reflected in low valuations. The crisis has aggravated this and will lead to a decline in revenues and an increase in non-performing loans. Consolidation could help reduce excess capacity 2/3

(THREAD) Negative quarter-on-quarter growth is the most realistic scenario for the end of the year, Vice-President Luis de Guindos tells @hsfi. We believe the recovery will start next year and continue in 2022. The main near-term issue is the availability of a vaccine 1/3 https://t.co/0zMG9LwLCL
Working paper: Interest rate risk and monetary policy normalisation in the euro https://t.co/2aLC1GDFhN
Working paper: Using forecast-augmented VAR evidence to dampen the forward guidance puzzle https://t.co/9MPjJxU21L

Climate change is getting more important for the economy and there is increasing evidence of its financial impact on banks. That’s why the next ECB supervisory stress test in 2022 will be on climate-related risks 3/3

The self-assessments need to be based on the ECB’s expectations outlined in the guide on climate-related and environmental risks. Read the full guide https://t.co/xHcsvPXaPE 2/3 https://t.co/QggPCPNZUk

(Thread) The ECB is stepping up its efforts to tackle climate risks. In 2021 we will use the supervisory dialogue to check and challenge bank’s self-assessments of and plans for how they manage climate risks. A full review will follow in 2022 https://t.co/N5pRPI5xc6 1/3

Panetta: A #digitaleuro would combine the efficiency of a digital payment instrument with the safety of central bank money, offering, together with cash, greater choice and access to simple ways of paying. Have your say in our public consultation https://t.co/cbioWMqpSc 5/5

Panetta: What is at stake is nothing short of the future of money. Sovereign money also needs to be reinvented. This requires central bank money to remain available in all circumstances: as cash and potentially as a digital euro. Read full speech https://t.co/nAaeFblC9R 4/5

Panetta: We are implementing a comprehensive policy to ensure that citizens’ payment needs are met, while safeguarding the integrity of the payment system and financial stability. We are also promoting safe, pan-European instant payments 3/5

Panetta: Big tech and stablecoins could disrupt the European financial system. While they could offer convenient and efficient payment solutions, they risk endangering competition, privacy, financial stability and even monetary sovereignty 2/5
